construction: This voltage doubler is driven by an AC voltage source, represented by the transformer shown above.  Nodes for this source have been given to you.  The capacitors are both 0.068 fards, and the load is 10,000 ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which you can include insider their expressions to avoid the clutter of separate knee voltage nodes.  Construct a model and graph the current through the load resistor.
execution: This is a model for a full wave voltage doubler that is driven by an AC voltage source, represented by the transformer shown above.  The capacitors are both 0.068 Farads, and the load is 10,000 ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which are include insider their expressions to avoid the clutter of separate knee voltage nodes.
incremental: This voltage doubler is driven by an AC voltage source, represented by the transformer shown above.  Nodes for this source have been given to you.  The capacitors are both 0.068 fards, and the load is 10,000 ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which you can include insider their expressions to avoid the clutter of separate knee voltage nodes.  Construct a model and graph the current through the load resistor.

givenModelNodes.name: AC input V
givenModelNodes.explanation: Voltage with respect to ground of point A, the top of the transformer's secondary winding.

givenModelNodes.name: Max input V
givenModelNodes.description: Height of peak of sinewave of AC input

givenModelNodes.name: wavelength
givenModelNodes.description: Duration of full cycle of sinewave

givenModelNodes.name: V across D1 if open
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage across diode D1 if it is reversed biased
givenModelNodes.explanation: Let's measure the voltage across the diode from anode to cathode, so that a positive voltage drop means the diode is forward-biased.  So if the voltage source swings positive, and the capacitor has some voltage across it measured from top to bottom, then the voltage across the diode (if it were open) is the voltage source minus the capacitor's voltage.

givenModelNodes.name: V across C1
givenModelNodes.explanation: When charged, voltage is positive on top. This capacitor charges when the voltage source swings positive and D1 conducts.  when the voltage source swings negative, D1 is reverse-baised, so the capacitor tries to discharge through the load and C2.

givenModelNodes.name: Charging C1
givenModelNodes.description: Change in voltage on C1 due to charging
givenModelNodes.explanation: When a capacitor is charging, the applied voltage is always a little ahead of the current voltage across the capacitor.  So find their difference and add that to the capacitor voltage in order to bring them to equality.

givenModelNodes.name: Discharging C1
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage change on C1 due to discharging
givenModelNodes.explanation: The voltage lost while discharging is the current divided by the capacitance.

givenModelNodes.name: V across D1
givenModelNodes.explanation: The usual diode behavior:  When the anode is more then 0.7 volts positive with respect to the cathode, then the diode is forward biased and drops 0.7 volts.  Otherwise, it is reverse biased and drops just as much as an open would.

givenModelNodes.name: V across C2
givenModelNodes.explanation: When charged, voltage is positive on top and negative on bottom.  This capacitor charges when the voltage source swings negative and D2 conducts.  When the voltage source is positive, D2 won't conduct, so the capacitor discharges through the load and C1.

givenModelNodes.name: Charging C2
givenModelNodes.description: Change in voltage on C2 due to charging
givenModelNodes.explanation: When a capacitor charges, its voltage is slightly less than the voltage applied across it.  To fill this gap, we find the differences between the two voltages, so that it can be added to the capacitor's voltage.

givenModelNodes.name: Discharging C2
givenModelNodes.explanation: The voltage lost while discharging is the current exiting the capacitor divided by its capacitance.

givenModelNodes.name: V across D2 if open
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage across diode D2 if reverse biased
givenModelNodes.explanation: The top of C2 is positive when it is charged and this side is attached to the bottom of the transformer.  So when the AC signal is high, this is like having two batteries in series, so their voltages sum.

givenModelNodes.name: V across D2
givenModelNodes.explanation: The usual diode behavior:  When the anode is more then 0.7 volts positive with respect to the cathode, then the diode is forward biased and drops 0.7 volts.  Otherwise, it is reverse biased and drops just as much as an open would.

givenModelNodes.name: V applied across C1
givenModelNodes.explanation: Because the voltage across C1 is measured top to bottom, if D1 is forward biased, then when the voltage source swings positive, the voltage across C1 almost equals the voltage source.  However, when the voltage source swings negative, then the diode drops all the voltage, leaving no voltage across the capacitor.

givenModelNodes.name: V applied across C2
givenModelNodes.explanation: Usually, the expression is "AC input - V across D"  and this is applied from bottom to top like C1.  However, the wires are reversed for C2, so we use -(AC input - V across D2) which simplifies to "V across D2 - AC input.
